title: [Articles] Effects of gender-affirming hormone therapy from adolescence to adulthood on bone mineral density, body composition and muscle strength
abstract: Long-term GAHT initiated during adolescence promotes alignment of bone density, body composition, and muscle strength consistent with gender identity, without evidence of clinically significant adverse effects. Modifiable lifestyle factors remain important determinants of skeletal health. Overall, participants reported good general health and life satisfaction.
authors: Silvia Ciancia, Jeroen Vervalcke, Daniel Klink, Guy T'Sjoen, Martine Cools

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Risk assessment of Cutaneous Leishmaniasis in the West Bank, Palestine: a case control study
abstract: CL remains endemic in parts of Palestine, particularly among children and rural populations. Socioeconomic and environmental factors play a critical role, highlighting the need for health education, improved housing, and vector control to reduce transmission.
authors: Rahmeh Daraghmeh, Raghad Sweity, Ihab K. Hemieid, Diyar Alajrami, ZainEdeen Zyadah, Amer Al-Jawabreh, Abedelmajeed Nasereddin, Suheir Ereqat

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Cost and impact of decentralized tuberculosis testing: a modeling analysis of price thresholds for molecular instruments in high-burden settings
abstract: At current prices, decentralized molecular TB testing is unlikely to be cost-effective, even with improved uptake, systemwide. However, meaningful reductions in instrument + warranty costs could make both full and partial decentralization viable. As countries face tighter budgets, clear price targets for cost-effectiveness can help guide procurement and investment decisions in TB diagnostics.
authors: Tom Ockhuisen, Alexandra de Nooy, Sarah Girdwood, Megan A. Hansen, Mikashmi Kohli, Morten Ruhwald, Nazir Ismail, Brooke E. Nichols

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Intraperitoneal and intravenous paclitaxel plus S-1 and sintilimab as first-line treatment for gastric cancer with peritoneal metastasis: a single-arm phase 2 trial (DRAGON-09)
abstract: First-line sintilimab and S-1 plus intraperitoneal and intravenous paclitaxel showed promising therapeutic efficacy in patients with GCPM.
authors: Hong Yuan, Sheng Lu, De-Bin Sun, Xue-Xin Yao, Wen-Tao Liu, Ya-Nan Zheng, Zi-Chen Hua, Zhen-Tian Ni, Chang-Yu He, Zhen-Qiang Wang, Jiao Zhang, Di Liu, Cen Jiang, Chen Li, Jun Zhang, Min Yan, Zhong-Yin Yang, Min Shi, Zheng-Gang Zhu, Chao Yan

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Sleep alterations in substance use disorders: a systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: These findings suggest specific relationships between specific addictive substances and sleep, highlight areas of convergence in these relationships, and indicate instances in which the same drug is related with both objective and subjective alterations. Further research is needed to explore further, at a meta-analytical level, relationships between sleep and specific substances.

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Major adverse cardiovascular events after liver transplantation: a population cohort analysis of English transplant centres
abstract: MACE and cardiovascular death are uncommon within the first-year post LT in England. However, liver transplant recipients with non-fatal MACE have inferior long-term survival. Further work is warranted to determine the best strategy to mitigate cardiac risk stratification for LT candidates and evidence-based strategies to mitigate cardiovascular risk after LT must be encouraged.
authors: Felicity Evison, Suzy Gallier, Fatima Malik, Charlotte Stephens, Charles J. Ferro, Jonathan Townend, William Moody, Matthew J. Armstrong, Adnan Sharif

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Artemether-lumefantrine versus pyronaridine-artesunate for the treatment of malaria in patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 in Kenya and Burkina Faso: a randomised open-label trial (MALCOV)
abstract: Pyronaridine-artesunate in COVID-19 patients co-infected with malaria was associated with slower viral clearance than standard treatment with artemether-lumefantrine but similar symptom resolution. Both treatments were highly effective as antimalarials and should continue to be considered first- or second-line treatment options for uncomplicated malaria in patients with mild to moderate COVID-19.

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Botulinum toxin for endometriosis-associated chronic pelvic pain: a randomised, double-masked, parallel, phase 2 trial
abstract: This study demonstrates the efficacy and safety of pelvic floor botulinum toxin injection for women with endometriosis-associated chronic pelvic pain and pelvic floor spasm.
authors: Barbara Illowsky Karp, Hannah K. Tandon, Ninet Sinaii, Jacqueline V. Aredo, Vy T. Phan, Noemi Salmeri, Jay P. Shah, Melissa A. Merideth, Pamela Stratton

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Experience of NHS diagnostic investigation following a multi-cancer early detection (MCED) screening test: qualitative interviews with NHS-Galleri trial participants who had a cancer signal detected
abstract: If MCED screening is implemented in future, it will be important to carefully consider implementation of appropriate diagnostic investigation for patients who have a cancer signal detected. We recommend minimising the length of the diagnostic testing period, offering patient navigation and formulating clear plans for what happens at the end of the patient journey. While our findings highlight important considerations to support positive experiences for those having follow-up tests after a cancer signal detected result, they also have broader application for improvement of cancer diagnostic pathways more generally.

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Cancer burden and risk factors among women with HIV: a multi-regional study from the D:A:D and RESPOND cohort collaborations
abstract: Our findings suggest that women with HIV older than 45 years, past or current immunosuppressed or current smokers could be candidates for intensified cancer screening and prevention.
authors: Win Min Han, Bastian Neesgaard, Michael Knappik, Matthias Cavassini, Irene A. journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Evaluating the short-term and long-term therapeutic effects of immunoadsorption compared with plasma exchange in chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy: a long-term, prospective, observational study
abstract: Our results suggest that repeated IA and PLEX might constitute promising therapeutic options in patients with CIDP who do not sufficiently respond to corticosteroids and IVIGs, stabilizing the disease in the majority of patients. However, its invasive nature and significant risk of jugular vein thromboses must be considered. Study limitations include non-randomised group allocation, retrospective collection of data related to preceding treatments, the possibility of sub-optimal treatment pre-baseline, the limited number of patients, and potential interfering elements (such as cross-overs between IA and PLEX) caused by the long observation time.

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Temporal trends in progression risk in smoldering myeloma: a systematic review
abstract: SMM appears to follow a more indolent trajectory in recent years, likely due to improved diagnostic precision and exclusion of biomarker-defined or subclinical MM. Enhanced predictive models may better guide therapeutic decision-making, targeting treatment to those most likely to benefit and avoiding the burden of unnecessary intervention in low-risk individuals.
authors: Heinz Ludwig, Efstathios Kastritis, Sarah Bernhard, Niels W.C.J. van de Donk, Mario Boccadoro, Evangelos Terpos, Pellegrino Musto, Pieter Sonneveld, Ghulam Rehman Mohyuddin

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] Gestational diabetes and stillbirth: a systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: Increased screening, timely diagnosis and effective management strategies for GDM in high-income countries, such as induction of labour and increased antenatal care, may be responsible for the reduced risk of stillbirth in women with GDM. Further research is needed to identify the optimum strategy for screening and management in low and middle-income settings to reduce preventable stillbirths worldwide.
authors: Victoria Bradley, Livia Samara, Miriam Toolan, Amelia Atkinson, Deborah M. Caldwell, Abigail Fraser, Shakila Thangaratinam, Gemma Clayton, Abi Merriel

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Articles] HCT Frailty Scale (HCT-FS) for assessing frailty in adult candidates for allogeneic haematopoietic cell transplantation: an international prospective, observational cohort study
abstract: The HCT-FS provided reliable measures of the frailty status of allo-HCT candidates that are informative for transplant outcomes, supporting its potential applicability in clinical practice. Notably, this tool was successfully integrated into clinical practice without additional resources. Future work is needed to further evaluate the applicability of the scale in transplant settings and whether targeted interventions based on can improve transplant outcomes.
authors: María Queralt Salas, Tommy Alfaro Moya, Ivan Pasic, Mónica Baile González, Marina Acera Gómez, Laura Fox, María del Mar Pérez Artigas, Ana Santamaría, María del Carmen Quintela González, Andrés Sánchez Salinas, Joaquina M. Salmerón Camacho, Verónica Illana Álvaro, Zahra Abdallahi-Lefdil, Javier Cornago Navascues, Laura Pardo, Sara Fernández-Luis, Leddy Patricia Vega Suárez, Sara Villar, Patricia Beorlegui-Murillo, Albert Esquirol, Isabel Izquierdo García, Alberto Mussetti, Esperanza Lavilla, Javier Lopez-Marín, Silvia Filaferro, Pascual Balsalobre, Leyre Bento, Arjun Law, Auro Viswabandya, Fotios V. Michelis, Jonas Mattsson, Shabbir Alibhai, Montserrat Rovira, Dennis Dong Wang Kim, Anna Sureda, Rajat Kumar

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Viewpoint] Prioritizing human-centered cancer care in a digital era
abstract: Digital health tools improve the efficiency and quality of cancer care and are poised to have an even greater impact in the future. However, the extent to which these tools will enhance both disease-centered and human-centered care depends on which values, outcomes, and processes diverse stakeholders and sectors prioritize. Human-centered care recognizes the uniqueness and inherent value of individuals and values the inimitability of human relationships. In this Viewpoint, we call for prioritization of human-centered care in the design and implementation of digital health tools.
authors: Grant Matthew Smith, Cristiane D. Bergerot, Andrew S. Epstein, Judith E. Nelson, Naveen Salins, Vasudeva Bhat K, Shirley Lewis, J. Mac Skelton, Ravi B. Parikh, Nirmala Bhoo-Pathy, Juan Borda, Beverley M. Essue, Loreto Fernandez-Gonzalez, Madeline Li, Nancy Preston, Gilla K. Shapiro, Dario Trapani, Karla Unger-Saldaña, Catherine Walshe, Camilla Zimmermann, Richard Sullivan, Gary Rodin, William E. Rosa

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Viewpoint] Twelve mutations, three trials, and five different labels: PARP inhibitors regulatory inconsistencies in prostate cancers
abstract: Three different PARP (Poly (ADP-ribose) Polymerase)-inhibitors have been approved in combination with androgen receptor pathway inhibitors (ARPIs) for the treatment of metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). Regulatory authorities, however, have divergent opinions. Although the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has limited approval of two PARP-inhibitors to patients with BRCA mutations or other alterations in homologous recombination repair (HRR) genes, the European Medicines Agency (EMA) has approved the indication for the overall mCRPC population, irrespective of HRR status.
authors: Sahar Barjesteh van Waalwijk van Doorn-Khosrovani, Hans M. Westgeest, Timothée Olivier

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Review] Health inequalities among people with disabilities: an umbrella review and evidence synthesis
abstract: People with disabilities are a diverse group, yet share the common experience of markedly worse health than their peers without disabilities. The evidence base is constrained by limited measurement of subjective health outcomes and definitions of disability that may not capture contextual factors. Consequently, the true association of disability and poor health outcomes may be underestimated. Health inequities experienced by people with disabilities necessitate health system reforms with efforts to embed inclusion and address social determinants of health.
authors: Tracey Smythe, Sara Rotenberg, Maureen Moyo-Chilufya, Jane Wilbur, Hannah Kuper

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Review] Outcome reporting for liver transplantation machine perfusion studies: a systematic review
abstract: There is significant variability in post-transplant complications reporting by LT with MP studies. Uniform definitions and standardized guidelines are critical to allow rigorous comparison of different perfusion techniques and other future innovations.
authors: Sangeeta Satish, Ayesha A. Qureshi, Fariba Abbassi, Muhammad A. Nadeem, Tobias Diwan, Laura Batista De Oliveira, Charles Miller, Koji Hashimoto, Chase J. Wehrle, Pierre-Alain Clavien, Andrea Schlegel

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Review] Navigating open data sharing and privacy in the age of clinical AI research: from reidentification to pseudo-reidentification
abstract: Sharing clinical research data is key for increasing the pace of medical discoveries that improve human health. However, concern about study participants' privacy, confidentiality, and safety is a major factor that deters researchers from openly sharing clinical data even after deidentification. This concern is further enhanced by the evolution of artificial intelligence (AI) approaches that pose an ever-increasing threat to the reidentification of study participants. Here, we discuss the challenges AI approaches create that are blurring the lines between identifiable, and non-identifiable data.
authors: Shahin Hallaj, Anna Heinke, Fritz Gerald P. Kalaw, Nayoon Gim, Marian Blazes, Julia Owen, Eamon Dysinger, Erik S. Benton, Benjamin A. Cordier, Nicholas G. Evans, Jennifer Li-Pook-Than, Michael P. Snyder, Camille Nebeker, Linda M. Zangwill, Sally L. Baxter, Shannon McWeeney, Cecilia S. Lee, Aaron Y. Lee, Bhavesh Patel, AI-READI Consortium

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Review] Machine learning for predicting clinical outcomes of hospitalised children: a systematic review of applications in low- and middle-income countries
abstract: We provided evidence of ML's promising performance for LMICs. Mortality prediction was the main focus. Arriving at clinical applications that benefit LMICs, requires investment in high-quality data and alignment to local (clinical) needs.
authors: William Nkhono, Eva van Lieshout, Job Calis, Violet Naanyu, Mark Hoogendoorn, Kamija S. Phiri, María Villalobos-Quesada

journal: eClinicalMedicine
title: [Review] Exploring the effects of pharmacological treatments on suicidality in children and adolescents: a structured review of the literature and narrative synthesis
abstract: Evidence remains scarce and heterogeneous. Esketamine and lithium appear promising for acute and chronic suicidality, respectively. Further high-quality studies investigating suicidal thoughts and behaviours as independent treatment targets are needed to guide clinical decision-making.
authors: Andrea Amerio, Enrico Venturini, Mirko Capanna, Luca Ploner, Irene Schiavetti, Alessandra Costanza, Massimiliano Clausi, Paola Bertuccio, Anna Odone, Helen Minnis, Ruchika Gajwani, Renato de Filippis, Pasquale De Fazio, Mario Amore, Andrea Aguglia, Gianluca Serafini

title: [Corrigendum] Corrigendum to ‘Two-year outcomes after selective early treatment of patent ductus arteriosus with ibuprofen in preterm babies: follow-up of Baby-OSCAR–a randomised controlled trial’ [eClinicalMedicine, Volume 87, September 2025, 103424]
abstract: During a routine review of the publication, the authors identified some errors in the numbers presented. The errors relate to:
authors: Samir Gupta, Heather O'Connor, Edmund Juszczak, Nimish V. Subhedar, Ursula Bowler, Charlotte Clarke, David Field, Elizabeth Hutchison, Wilf Kelsall, Justine Pepperell, Tracy Roberts, Sunil Sinha, Kayleigh Stanbury, Jonathan Wyllie, Pollyanna Hardy, Samantha Johnson, Baby-OSCAR Collaborative Group

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Editorial] Addressing the issue of ultra-processed foods
abstract: Ultra-processed foods (UPFs), often recognisable by their brightly coloured packaging, convenience, long shelf lives, and palatable flavours, are aggressively marketed to individuals across the lifespan. UPFs are defined by the NOVA system as the most processed food group; they contain little to no whole-food ingredients and are instead made from food derivatives and additives. Consumption of UPFs has been increasing across the world in recent years, despite concerns about their long-term health effects for consumers of all ages.

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Correspondence] Measuring what matters in ageing societies: integrating dying-well and living-well metrics for resilient health systems
abstract: We read with interest the Personal View by Rowan Harwood and colleagues in Lancet Healthy Longevity, in which they introduce a logic model outlining candidate variables for monitoring the quality of dying.1 While rightly emphasising the contentious nature of a universal good death and the related data challenges, the authors offer practical recommendations towards a measurement framework aligned with the UN Decade of Healthy Ageing.2 This article prompts a key question: how do we measure what matters most across the life course?

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Correspondence] Temporality might matter in people with atrial fibrillation and heart failure
abstract: In their Article in The Lancet Healthy Longevity, Nicholas R Jones and colleagues1 provide valuable insight into the long-term prognosis of people with atrial fibrillation and heart failure using nationwide linked primary and secondary care data from England. Their study confirms the persistently high mortality associated with the coexistence of atrial fibrillation and heart failure and the absence of major survival improvement since 2000.
authors: Laurent Fauchier, Matthieu Nasarre, Thibaud Lenormand

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Correspondence] Temporality might matter in people with atrial fibrillation and heart failure
abstract: We thank Professor Laurent Fauchier and colleagues for their interest in our analysis.1 We agree that the order in which heart failure and atrial fibrillation develop is of interest and might well be important with respect to prognosis. Previous research has reported that for people with incident atrial fibrillation, the presence of prevalent heart failure is an important predictor of all-cause mortality, whereas for people with incident heart failure, survival is similar among people with or without established atrial fibrillation.
authors: Nicholas R Jones, Margaret Smith, Yaling Yang, F D Richard Hobbs, Clare J Taylor

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Articles] Potentially modifiable risk factors for dementia in Norway (HUNT4 70+): a retrospective cohort study
abstract: Addressing all 14 Lancet risk factors could prevent over half of all dementia cases. Adding factors related to marital and occupational status offers additional preventive potential, particularly among women.
authors: Merete Ellingjord-Dale, Bjørn Heine Strand, Vegard Skirbekk, Bernt Bratsberg, Teferi Mekonnen, Ekaterina Zotcheva, Geir Selbæk, Yaakov Stern, Asta Kristine Håberg, Bo Engdahl

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Articles] Menopause hormone therapy and risk of mild cognitive impairment or dementia: a systematic review and meta-analysis
abstract: This review found no evidence that MHT use either increases or decreases the risk of dementia in post-menopausal women. This reinforces current clinical guidance, that MHT prescription should be based on other perceived benefits and risks and not for dementia prevention. High-quality, long-term studies are needed to clarify the role of MHT and dementia risk, particularly regarding formulation, dose, route, timing, and duration of treatment, with a focus on women with premature ovarian insufficiency, early menopause, or mild cognitive impairment.
authors: Melissa Melville, Lexi He, Roopal Desai, Primrose Nyamayaro, Chris Fox, Kavita U Kothari, Patrick Condron, Miao Miao, Martha Hickey, Aimee Spector

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Articles] Frailty and prognosis of biomarker-confirmed Alzheimer’s disease: a Swedish, register-based, retrospective cohort study
abstract: Frailty, measured by the frailty index, predicted institutionalisation and mortality in people with Alzheimer’s disease, but its absence of association with cognitive decline suggests neurodegeneration as the primary driver.
authors: Xin Xia, Maria Eriksdotter, Henrik Zetterberg, Silke Kern, Tobias Skillbäck, Marco Toccaceli Blasi, Bengt Winblad, Jonathan K L Mak, Alice Margherita Ornago, Elena Pinardi, Román Romero Ortuño, Linus Jönsson

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Articles] The association of pain with intrinsic capacity and the moderating role of inflammation in France: a cross-sectional analysis of the INSPIRE-T project
abstract: Pain was associated with reduced intrinsic capacity, with no evidence of a moderating role of iAge in this association. Higher pain intensities were linked to lower scores in all domains defining intrinsic capacity, except the sensory domain. At moderate intensities, the association was particularly evident in the vitality, locomotor, and psychological domains. Further research is needed to determine whether effective pain management could help prevent declines in intrinsic capacity.
authors: Federico Bellelli, Jeremy Raffin, Matteo Cesari, Sophie Guyonnet, David Furman, Yves Rolland, Bruno Vellas, Philipe de Souto Barreto, IHU HealthAge INSPIRE Platform Group, IHU HealthAge Open Science group

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Articles] Safety outcomes of trazodone versus antipsychotics for delirium after hospital admission in adults aged 65 years and older: a nationwide cohort study using a target trial emulation framework
abstract: These results revealed reduced risks of rehospitalisation and all-cause mortality associated with trazodone versus atypical antipsychotic medications. Trazodone is a potentially safer alternative to antipsychotic medications in the management of delirium-related symptoms after hospital discharge.
authors: Chun-Ting Yang, James M Wilkins, Kevin T Pritchard, Qiaoxi Chen, Xiaojuan Liu, Dae Hyun Kim, Kueiyu Joshua Lin

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Articles] Clinical effectiveness of music interventions for dementia and depression in older people (MIDDEL): a multinational, cluster-randomised controlled trial
abstract: Internationally, active group music interventions as conducted in this study do not reduce depressive symptoms more than standard care in the long term. Country was the strongest predictor for differences in effects, underlining the importance of cultural and systemic differences. Intervention guidelines and health-care policies need to be carefully tailored to the specific contexts of care home populations and levels of care. Future multisite trials should focus on more narrowly defined target groups or contexts to reduce the risk of heterogeneity overshadowing potential effects of interventions.
authors: Vigdis Sveinsdottir, Jörg Assmus, Justine Schneider, Felicity A Baker, Burçin Uçaner, Gunter Kreutz, Monika Geretsegger, Naomi Rasing, Jodie Bloska, Phoebe A Stretton-Smith, Young-Eun C Lee, Jo Dugstad Wake, Helen Odell-Miller, Jeanette Tamplin, Annemieke C Vink, Joanne Ablewhite, Johanna Neuser, Ulrike Frischen, Antje Timmer, Thomas Wosch, Sarah Janus, Christian Gold

journal: The Lancet Healthy Longevity
title: [Review] Oropharyngeal dysphagia: a narrative review towards an integrated neurogeriatric perspective
abstract: Oropharyngeal dysphagia, prevalent in neurogeriatric populations, increases the risks of malnutrition, pneumonia, and mortality. Oropharyngeal dysphagia manifests as a multi-aetiological syndrome with diverse phenotypes. We advocate for a neurogeriatric perspective that integrates specific neurological insights with geriatric care principles to improve dysphagia management. This approach highlights the diagnostic value of disease-specific neurological dysphagia manifestations and recognises the condition as a potential target for neurological therapies, as shown by the benefits that acetylcholinesterase inhibitors in myasthenia gravis and dopaminergic agents in Parkinson's disease have against the syndrome.
authors: Bendix Labeit, Sriramya Lapa, Gero Lueg, Rebecca Joebges, Jule Hofacker, Paul Muhle, Sonja Suntrup-Krueger, Cornelius J Werner, Stefanie Schreiber, Rainer Wirth, Tobias Warnecke, Rainer Dziewas, Sven G Meuth

abstract: The Original Investigation titled “Dexmedetomidine- or Clonidine-Based Sedation Compared With Propofol in Critically Ill Patients: the A2B Randomized Clinical Trial,” published on May 19, 2025, was corrected to fix the baseline variables of age, sex, weight, RASS score prior to randomization, and CAM-ICU status prior to randomization in Table 1 because incorrect criteria had been used to select participants for the data summary, leading to a divergence from the prespecified analysis population. journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: ARNI Over ACEI Lacks Clinical Benefit in Patients With Chagas Cardiomyopathy
abstract: Chagas cardiomyopathy is the most common presentation of the determinate form of Trypanosoma cruzi infection and carries a worse prognosis than other common causes of heart failure. The 3 most common causes of death from Chagas cardiomyopathy are sudden cardiac death due to malignant ventricular arrhythmias, progression of heart failure, and, less frequently, thromboembolic events. Although traditionally a neglected disease in Latin America, the impact of Chagas cardiomyopathy is no longer confined to historically endemic areas, owing to population migration and northward expansion of the vector habitats. Chagas cardiomyopathy is endemic in the US, with autochthonous transmission (ie, transmission originating within the local environment) reported in at least 8 southern US states. Over the past 2 decades, there has been a growing recognition of Chagas cardiomyopathy, with dedicated clinical research uncovering key disease-specific insights. Potential preventive and therapeutic strategies include traditional infectious disease approaches aimed at parasite eradication as well as interventions directed at the cardiac manifestation of disease, such as reducing and treating arrhythmic burden and optimizing guideline-directed medical therapy.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Sacubitril/Valsartan vs Enalapril in Heart Failure Due to Chagas Disease
abstract: This randomized clinical trial examines the safety and efficacy of guideline-recommended treatments for patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction caused by Chagas disease.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Shroud
abstract: Before I canceled his phone there were the photos— Spain, Morocco, the cabin, close-ups of construction sites, the rooftop garden and harvest. The last image, repeated ten times, a close-up of a blanket. White. Woven.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Poetry and Seeing the Body After Death
abstract: For most clinicians, our first patients are the cadavers of those who have donated their bodies to medical science. However, few encounter the remains of those who die under our care after final illness. Given poetry’s long history of being incorporated into the funerary practices of many cultures—it decorates the tombs of ancient Greeks, Romans, and Chinese; is raised on runestones that mark Viking graves; and guided the ancient Egyptian dead to the afterlife—it may be useful in preserving a connection to the physical presence of the deceased. In “Shroud,” the speaker enlists poetry in just this way, with imagery that at once provides the comfort of a traditional death shroud while ironically making her lost loved one indelibly visible, if only in memory. The shroud itself is a white hospital blanket that persists in last photos taken with a smartphone; these and other images, which the speaker taps through in deciding which ones to keep, are themselves a kind of protective cover, artifacts that specifically conjure “…a man who could lift,/make, or fix anything.” Finally, it is the poem itself that both enshrouds the lost “sweetheart” while invoking his undying physicality. After recalling the recent cremation of a friend’s father, complete with blanket and playing cards enveloping the body before being committed to flame, the poem’s uncanny last lines (almost) return “Aaron” to life: “…as you clicked away on your phone,/did you think you were reheating your coffee,/raising your legs in the recliner,/changing the channel?”

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Sacubitril/Valsartan vs Enalapril in Heart Failure Due to Chagas Disease Research Summary
abstract: This trial aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of sacubitril/valsartan compared with enalapril in patients with heart failure (HF) with reduced ejection fraction due to Chagas disease.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Levosimendan and Weaning From VA-ECMO
abstract: Venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) is increasingly used to treat patients with cardiogenic shock, a life-threatening condition with persistently high mortality rates. However, patients receiving VA-ECMO are at risk of major complications, including acute limb ischemia, infection, bleeding, thromboembolic events, and stroke; thus, it would be advantageous if a therapy allowed more rapid weaning and liberation from the VA-ECMO circuit.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Alcohol and Cancer
abstract: To the Editor Dr Morford and colleagues published an astute JAMA Insights summarizing the evidence supporting the 2025 US Surgeon General’s Advisory on alcohol and cancer risk and posing important clinical recommendations. We commend the authors for compiling these data and advocating that clinicians implement alcohol use screening. We seek to bolster their clinical recommendations.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Alcohol and Cancer—Reply
abstract: In Reply We appreciate the thoughtful Letter by Dr Streck and colleagues regarding our article summarizing the evidence on alcohol and cancer risk. We support their emphasis on screening for a broad spectrum of substances, including opioids, stimulants, cannabis, and nicotine, acknowledging the prevalence and impact of polysubstance use and SUDs in the general population and oncology treatment settings.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Levosimendan to Facilitate Weaning From ECMO in Patients With Severe Cardiogenic Shock
abstract: This randomized clinical trial assesses the effect of levosimendan on weaning from venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) within 30 days among patients with severe but potentially reversible cardiogenic shock.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Levosimendan to Facilitate Weaning From ECMO in Patients With Severe Cardiogenic Shock Research Summary
abstract: This study aimed to determine if early levosimendan administration shortens the time to successful weaning from venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) in adult patients with severe, potentially reversible cardiogenic shock.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Combination-Only Approvals as a Barrier to Affordable HIV Care
abstract: This Viewpoint discusses the barrier that combination-only antiretroviral therapy drugs have been to access of affordable HIV care.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Trends in Injecting Methamphetamine and Opioids Among People Who Inject Drugs in the US
abstract: This study examines trends in injecting methamphetamine and opioids among people who inject drugs entering drug treatment in the US.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Suicides and Overdoses During the 2023 Wildfires in Maui, Hawaiʻi
abstract: To the Editor We read with interest the study by Dr Purtle and colleagues examining suicide and overdose deaths following the 2023 Maui wildfires. The study addresses an important public health concern, but its conclusions extend beyond what the observational design can support.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Suicides and Overdoses During the 2023 Wildfires in Maui, Hawaiʻi—Reply
abstract: In Reply In response to our article, Dr Busch raises concerns about conflating correlation with causation and questions the public health significance of the excess suicide and overdose deaths that may be attributable to the August 2023 Maui wildfires. We write to clarify what we believe are misinterpretations and to further justify our conclusions. Importantly, we underscore that in a small and tightly connected community such as Maui, even modest absolute increases in suicides or overdoses represent a profound public health concern. Each death carries significant weight, both statistically and socially, and contributes to the collective trauma of a community already experiencing immense loss. The suggestion that such increases are too small to matter overlooks the disproportionate impact of each life lost in smaller populations.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Informing Patients About Use of AI Tools
abstract: To the Editor Dr Mello and colleagues argue that the need to inform patients of artificial intelligence (AI) use in health care depends on the risk of physical harm to patients from the AI system and patients’ ability to meaningfully act on any disclosure. According to this proposed framework, many potential AI uses in health care, such as AI-assisted imaging interpretation, do not require patient awareness or agreement.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Informing Patients About Use of AI Tools—Reply
abstract: In Reply In their Letter, Dr Weightman and colleagues argue that because many patients may wish to be informed about uses of AI in their care, AI use should always be disclosed. We have argued instead that the ethical obligation to notify patients depends on (1) the seriousness of the physical risk and (2) the extent to which patients have a meaningful opportunity to exercise agency in response to a notification.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: Medically Tailored Groceries for Blood Pressure Control
abstract: The concept of “food is medicine” has gained momentum as a strategy to integrate food-based nutritional interventions into health care as a therapy to manage and treat chronic diseases. Yet despite its intuitive appeal and growing health care, public, and policy interest, the field remains limited by a paucity of randomized clinical trials that evaluate real-world implementation and clinical outcomes. A study published in JAMA, the GoFresh trial by Juraschek et al, represents an important contribution to the evidence base, testing whether home-delivered groceries patterned after the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet can improve blood pressure among Black adults living in “food desert” neighborhoods.

journal: JAMA Current Issue
title: DASH-Patterned Groceries and Effects on Blood Pressure
abstract: This randomized clinical trial investigates the effect of home-delivered Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) low-sodium groceries on blood pressure among Black adults in communities with few grocery stores.

journal: JAMA Online First
title: The Rise of Therapy Chatbots
abstract: This Medical News article discusses the growing use of generative artificial intelligence chatbots as sources of mental health support.

journal: JAMA Online First
title: 6 Takeaways from the WHO’s First Obesity Drug Guideline
abstract: This Medical News article discusses key learnings from new World Health Organization guidance on the use of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) medications for the treatment of obesity in adults.

journal: JAMA Online First
title: Safe and Sufficient—Ibuprofen for Pediatric Musculoskeletal Injuries
abstract: Pain is among the leading reasons that children and adolescents (hereafter, youth) seek care in emergency departments (EDs). One of the most common causes is musculoskeletal injury, including nonoperative fractures, sprains, and strains. Such injuries can lead to significant distress for youth and their families, and clinicians have long wrestled with how best to balance pain relief with risk, ensuring that youth are comfortable while also avoiding unnecessary exposure to opioids. Undertreatment of pain contributes not only to unnecessary discomfort, but potentially also to impaired recovery from the injury, heightened future pain sensitivity, and long-term effects on psychosocial well-being and quality of life. However, a rise in prescription opioid–related overdoses in the 2000s and the high prevalence of adolescent opioid use disorder—now affecting approximately 1 in 100 adolescents aged 12 to 17 years—has sharpened attention to the risks of opioids. Still, many parents and clinicians remain concerned that without opioids, pain from an injury will not be adequately addressed.

journal: JAMA Online First
title: Stillbirth
abstract: This JAMA Insights focuses on stillbirth, including causes, risk factors, and prenatal preventive care.

journal: JAMA Online First
title: A Nutritional Outlook
abstract: The World War served to focus attention in a popular way on the problems of human nutrition to an extent never observed before. The appeal of the United States Food Administration to the nation asserted that all our questions centered in food: its production, its distribution, its use, its conservation. “The more you know about these things,” Mr. Hoover exhorted, “the more valuable you will be and the greater will be your service to humanity.” During our first year as a belligerent (April 1, 1917, to April 1, 1918) we exported fifteen billion pounds of food—an increase of more than 200 per cent over the prewar average. The food shipped was enough to ration completely more than 21,000,000 men, and to supply a considerable surplus of protein-rich foods and fats besides. Much of this surplus was the result of the saving of the American people. This was done in spite of the fact that the estimated total production of the country for the fiscal year, in terms of nutritional units, was from 7 to 10 per cent below the average of the previous years.

journal: JAMA Online First
title: Interim Safety of RSVpreF Vaccination During Pregnancy
abstract: This interim analysis of an ongoing retrospective cohort study uses data from 5 US health plans to assess safety of a bivalent prefusion F subunit–based respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) vaccine administered during pregnancy during the first full RSV season after US Food and Drug Administration approval (from September 22, 2023, through June 14, 2024).

journal: JAMA Online First
title: AI in Peer Review
abstract: To the Editor Dr Perlis and colleagues highlight the potential role of artificial intelligence (AI) in peer review and propose cautious, hybrid strategies for integration. We agree that AI will inevitably shape editorial workflows, but we wish to emphasize a complementary point of view: the need to prioritize training, evaluation, and quality enhancement over mere acceleration of the review process.

journal: JAMA Online First
title: AI in Peer Review—Reply
abstract: In Reply We appreciate the thoughtful reminder by Dr Zavaleta-Monestel and colleagues that quality, efficiency, and integrity, in addition to speed, are critical elements of quality peer review. In our Editorial, we aimed to express their caution, and optimism, that appropriately vetted AI tools will contribute to these important aims. Many of the considerations explored in a recent JAMA AI Summit report apply equally to applications of AI in peer review. Our previous guidance to peer reviewers and authors addresses the important issues regarding transparency, rigor, and integrity in the use of AI, as well as the need for centrality of humans in this process.﻿ JAMA has launched a Peer Review Academy in recognition of the need to broaden the pool of peer reviewers and maintain the centrality of humans in this loop, even as we seek to provide these humans with better tools.

journal: JAMA Online First

In addition, the funding statement was changed to reflect that it was Dr Mukherjee who was funded by the Vanderbilt University Medical Center internal career development award rather than Dr Martin-Pozo. This article was corrected online.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Rethinking End Points in Modern Oncology Trials—Beyond the  P  Value
abstract: To the Editor We read with great interest the meta-epidemiological analysis of modern phase 3 cancer trials by Sherry et al. Clarifying several points would be helpful.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Rethinking End Points in Modern Oncology Trials—Beyond the  P  Value
abstract: To the Editor We read with great interest the meta-epidemiological analysis by Sherry et al of 791 phase 3 oncology trials. The authors reported that only 28% of trials demonstrated an overall survival (OS) benefit and only 11% showed a global quality-of-life (QoL) improvement. They concluded that QoL appears both underevaluated and underreported and note that most QoL analyses were unadjusted for baseline, which lose efficiency and add bias compared with baseline-adjusted methods. We commend this study but would like to discuss several methodological and interpretative issues.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Rethinking End Points in Modern Oncology Trials—Beyond the  P  Value—Reply
abstract: In Reply We appreciate the interest in our study regarding overall survival (OS) and quality of life (QoL) in phase 3 oncology trials.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Errors in Results and Figure 2
abstract: The Original Investigation titled “Noninferiority of Hypofractionated vs Conventional Postprostatectomy Radiotherapy for Genitourinary and Gastrointestinal Symptoms: The NRG-GU003 Phase 3 Randomized Clinical Trial,” published online March 14, 2024, and in the May 2024 issue of JAMA Oncology, contained errors in the Results section as well as Figure 2. An incorrect follow-up time variable was used to calculate the time to first grade 3 adverse event, which affected the analysis presented in Figure 2 and the corresponding hazard ratio, 95% CI, and P value reported in the text (the correct hazard ratio is 0.89; 95% CI, 0.51-1.55; P = .46). Additionally, the correct estimate (SE) and P value for bowel scores in follow-up were 0.57 (0.06); P < .001. These corrections do not change the study’s overall conclusions or interpretations. This article was corrected online.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Do All Breast Cancer Survivors Need to See a Cardiologist?
abstract: Little is known about the contribution of breast cancer treatments to the long-term development of heart failure (HF) and/or cardiomyopathy (CM) in patients. For some treatments (eg, anthracyclines), specific recommendations for cardiac surveillance are based on the total cumulative dose received. For ERBB2 (formerly HER2)-targeted treatments, monitoring largely occurs in the setting of active treatment, with little guidance for subsequent surveillance or risk assessment. The expanding number of breast cancer survivors, with cardiovascular disease as an important competing cause of mortality, brings attention to understanding who is at risk for HF/CM after breast cancer treatments and whether preventive cardiac surveillance is warranted.

However, the lack of statistical power analysis for rare tumor subtypes, like breast and colorectal cancers, limits interpretation of null findings.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Unexpected Results of Induction Chemotherapy vs Adjuvant Chemotherapy
abstract: To the Editor We read with interest the results of the phase 3 randomized clinical trial by Guo et al that investigated the important question if induction chemotherapy (IC) was superior to adjuvant chemotherapy (AC) when added to a backbone of concurrent chemoradiotherapy (CCRT) in patients with N2-3 nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). For IC, the investigators used the triplet combination of paclitaxel-cisplatin-fluorouracil (TPF), whereas doublet cisplatin-fluorouracil (PF) was used for AC. The trial was powered to detect a 12% difference in progression-free survival (PFS) in favor of IC, and enrolled 324 patients, with 162 patients in each group. However, this was a negative trial with comparable 3-year PFS between IC plus CCRT and CCRT plus AC, contrasting the results of the NPC-0501 trial by the Hong Kong NPC study group, which showed an improvement for PFS in favor of IC, albeit subtle differences exist between both trials. Intriguingly, in the present study, IC was associated with poorer local control compared with AC.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Unexpected Results of Induction Chemotherapy vs Adjuvant Chemotherapy—Reply
abstract: In Reply On behalf of my coauthors, I thank Chua and Lim for taking the time to read our article and share their thoughtful comments.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Limitations in Quantitative Harm-Benefit Assessment in Immuno-Oncology
abstract: To the Editor Heyward et al presented an important contribution to the growing literature on outcomes of immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) in older adults with non–small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). By linking Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER)–Medicare data with modern treatment records, the authors attempted to quantify the trade-off between survival gains and immune-related adverse events (irAEs) associated with ICI-based regimens. Their key finding that ICI plus chemotherapy in first-line systemic therapy resulted in improved survival at the cost of increased severe irAEs is both clinically meaningful and methodologically ambitious. We believe that several aspects of the analytic approach and interpretation warrant further discussion.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: Limitations in Quantitative Harm-Benefit Assessment in Immuno-Oncology
abstract: To the Editor The study by Heyward and colleagues addresses a critical unmet need in immuno-oncology: quantifying clinical trade-offs between survival gains and immune-related toxic effects in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) subgroups typically excluded from clinical trials. Their novel harm-benefit metric, excess severe immune-related adverse events (irAEs) per life-year gained, provides actionable insights for personalized decision making, particularly in older adults and patients with autoimmune diseases where clinical evidence remains scarce.

journal: JAMA Oncology Current Issue
title: The Breakup Letter
abstract: Dear Hair, We must break up. I hope it’s only a trial separation. It’s not me, it’s not you, It’s cancer. I will miss pinning you up, or wearing you down, Depending if I’m up or down. And the tension of a ponytail, is a dull ache I now grieve. Or the graceless frizz from rain’s humidity. I long to curse my gray hair, And pay too much for its disguise. But vanity has no place in my furious fight, To one day brush a head of silver. And my battle requires a hairless skull. To scare cancer back to hell.

journal: JAMA Oncology Online First
title: Enlightening a Path Forward for Patients With Advanced Acral Melanoma
abstract: Acral melanoma represents a subset of cutaneous melanoma that arises from the palms of the hands, the soles of the feet, or the nail beds. It has several unique characteristics including a similar incidence rate across different race and ethnic groups, is associated with a poorer prognosis than in nonacral cutaneous melanoma independent of therapy, and shares genomic similarities with mucosal melanoma vis-à-vis low tumor mutational burden and high copy number variations. Critically, acral melanoma is associated with poorer outcomes to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) than nonacral cutaneous melanoma, and the data guiding the use of ICIs in acral melanoma have been limited to retrospective series and subgroup analyses of larger prospective trials.

abstract: Mission Statement: To advance the patient-centered, evidence-based practice of otolaryngology–head and neck surgery by publishing scientifically rigorous and innovative research, reviews, and commentary. Our journal serves as a vital resource for clinicians, researchers, educators, and trainees by providing high-quality, peer-reviewed content focused on improving the understanding and treatment of ear, nose, and throat conditions. We are dedicated to fostering dialogue and action on critical issues in otolaryngology, including the education and training of health care professionals, quality improvement, and the ethics and economics of equitable health care delivery.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Shifting the AI Questions in Otolaryngology
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has generated remarkable enthusiasm in medicine, and otolaryngology is no exception. Yet current literature remains limited in scope and quality, dominated by feasibility studies using single-institution, internally validated datasets. Without a shift in direction, early excitement may collapse into unmet expectations. In this issue of JAMA Otolaryngology−Head & Neck Surgery, Novi et al highlight the innovation and promise of AI and deep learning (DL) in otolaryngology, a field rich in data, from endoscopy and microscopy to electrophysiology. They also underscore the growing chasm between proof-of-concept studies and applications meaningfully improving patient care. Bridging this gap requires moving beyond feasibility toward rigorous evaluation and clinically relevant implementation.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Balloon Sinus Dilation—To Inflate or Not to Inflate
abstract: The current issue of JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery presents a collection of 3 articles that highlight an ethical and moral medical dilemma in the otolaryngology community that has surrounded the use of balloon sinus dilation (BSD) since it was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration in 2005 for therapeutic and diagnostic approaches to the paranasal sinuses. Since its approval, BSD has been used as a stand-alone procedure with or without general anesthesia, as well as part of a hybrid procedure in conjunction with endoscopic sinus surgery. Interestingly, the explosion of BSD use has not decreased the amount of endoscopic sinus surgeries performed annually. According to recent clinical consensus statements, BSD may be used for limited chronic paranasal sinus disease and in cases of recurrent acute rhinosinusitis and is not indicated for management of headache or obstructive sleep apnea or in cases of absent pathology on computed tomography (CT) or imaging.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Balloon Sinus Dilation Use
abstract: This cross-sectional study analyzes use of balloon sinuplasty after the 2018 publication of the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery’s clinical consensus statement defining its appropriate indications and use.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Updated Calcitonin Thresholds More Accurately Predict Lymph Node Metastasis?
abstract: To the Editor I read with great interest the recent study by Du et al, “Updated Thresholds of Basal Calcitonin Level and Extent of Lymph Node Metastasis in Initially Treated Medullary Thyroid Cancer,” and the accompanying Invited Commentary. However, the results reported in Table 2 appear internally inconsistent, possibly due to transposing of the sensitivity and specificity columns for American Thyroid Association (ATA) serum calcitonin thresholds of 20, 50, and 500 pg/mL (to convert to picomoles per liter, multiply by 0.292); however, for 200 pg/mL, they seem correct. The ATA thresholds were originally chosen to minimize the false negative rate. In this context, the reported very low sensitivity for the 50 pg/mL cutoff—implying a very high false negative rate—is implausible, as is the correspondingly very high specificity; the same applies for the cutoff values of 50 and 500 pg/mL.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Updated Calcitonin Thresholds More Accurately Predict Lymph Node Metastasis?—Reply
abstract: In Reply We thank Colli for his thoughtful comments on our study. We would like to provide a detailed clarification to address what we believe a misunderstanding regarding our updated thresholds. First, we fully agree that the ATA thresholds seek to minimize missed LNMs by adopting very low preoperative calcitonin cutoffs. However, this inevitably leads to an extremely high rate of overtreatment, resulting in unnecessary complications and surgical morbidity. For example, under the current cutoffs, patients newly diagnosed with medullary thyroid cancer and with preoperative calcitonin greater than 20 pg/mL would be considered for lateral neck dissection. In our data, patients with calcitonin levels of 20 to 50 pg/mL had 5-year structural recurrence-free survival rates of 92.1% and 100% in the training and validation cohorts, respectively, with no recurrences observed in the validation cohort, comparable to 92.7% and 93.0% in the 241.9 to 693.9 pg/mL group. Thus, prophylactic neck dissection in patients with calcitonin levels of 20 to 50 pg/mL would likely lead to substantial overtreatment.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Caution Comparing Transoral Ultrasonography With Postbiopsy Magnetic Resonance Imaging
abstract: To the Editor I read with great interest the article by Garset-Zamani et al. I was not surprised that the sensitivity of ultrasonography and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) were similar, but the substantially inferior specificity of MRI was surprising and, on close reading, may be due to bias introduced by several of the study methods.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Oral Steroids for Postthyroidectomy Unilateral Vocal Fold Paralysis
abstract: To the Editor We read the randomized clinical trial by Carvajal-Alegria et al with great interest. The authors are to be commended for conducting a rigorous placebo-controlled trial on the use of oral corticosteroids for unilateral vocal fold paralysis (UVFP) following thyroid surgery. While their findings suggest no benefit on vocal fold remobilization, we believe this conclusion warrants discussion regarding 4 critical aspects: the therapeutic window, injury-specific mechanisms, patient-centered end points, and the potential of multimodal therapy.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Oral Steroids for Postthyroidectomy Unilateral Vocal Fold Paralysis
abstract: To the Editor Unilateral postoperative vocal cord paralysis is a rare (3.5%) complication that is typically temporary. It is frequently caused by neurapraxia of the recurrent laryngeal nerve as a result of manipulation, traction, or inflammation during surgery. Glucocorticoids have demonstrated clinically significant improvement in cases of neurapraxia with facial paralysis.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Caution Comparing Transoral Ultrasonography With Postbiopsy Magnetic Resonance Imaging—Reply
abstract: In Reply We appreciate Guenette’s interest in our recent article on the use of surgeon-performed transoral ultrasonography for the diagnostic workup of oropharyngeal cancers. We apologize that there has been an error in the text (for which a correction note has been published), which may have given the impression that magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) results were known when transoral ultrasonography was performed. To clarify, the transoral ultrasonography was performed as an extension of the clinical examination during the patient’s first visit to the outpatient cancer clinic. MRI was performed afterwards; therefore, the transoral ultrasonography was blinded to the MRI and biopsy results. Our exclusion criteria also stated that any participants with available cross-sectional imaging at their first visit were not included.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Oral Steroids for Postthyroidectomy Unilateral Vocal Fold Paralysis—Reply
abstract: In Reply We thank Rodríguez Cano and Sanabria as well as Huang et al for their insightful comments on our randomized clinical trial that assessed oral corticosteroids in unilateral vocal fold paralysis after thyroid or parathyroid surgery. Their observations allow us to expand on several methodological and clinical aspects of this pilot study.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Outcome Prediction in Older Adults With Head and Neck Cancer Undergoing Chemoradiation
abstract: This cohort study develops and externally validates artificial neural networks for overall survival and progression-free survival in older adults with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma undergoing definitive chemoradiation.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Proton Beam vs Intensity-Modulated Radiotherapy in Olfactory Neuroblastoma
abstract: This cohort study investigates if there are differences in the effectiveness and radiation treatment–related adverse events between adjuvant intensity-modulated radiotherapy and proton beam radiotherapy for patients with olfactory neuroblastoma.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Gingival Swelling and Frequent Epistaxis in an Older Woman
abstract: A 69-year-old woman was referred due to widespread gingival swelling, which had been worsening over the preceding 3 months and was unresponsive to antibiotic treatment. Gingival biopsy showed areas of chronic inflammation, microabscess foci, and pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia of the covering epithelium. What is your diagnosis?

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Protecting the Contralateral Palatine Tonsil
abstract: To the Editor We applaud Peterson et al for revisiting the question of whether to routinely remove the nondiseased tonsil during transoral robotic surgery (TORS) for human papillomavirus (HPV)–associated palatine tonsil squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Their well-executed retrospective analysis demonstrates clinically meaningful increases in hemorrhage, 30-day emergency department visits/hospitalizations, and hospital stays after bilateral compared with unilateral palatine tonsillectomy, with similar rates of second primary diagnoses and equivalent survival outcomes. Although previous literature has endorsed routine removal of the contralateral palatine tonsil as standard of care to prevent the emergence of second primary tumors, valid counterpoints to this argument should be considered.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: A Rare Presentation of a Sinonasal Tumor
abstract: This case report describes a 36-year-old patient with severe hyponatremia.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Olfaction and Risk of Coronary Heart Disease
abstract: This cohort study examines the association of olfaction with risk of coronary heart disease in older adults.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Woman Presenting With Calvarial Mass
abstract: A 48-year-old woman presented with episodic headaches, light sensitivity, and a painful, pulsating mass on her forehead. What is your diagnosis?

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Patient With a Cough and Calcified Cervical Lymphadenopathy
abstract: A 66-year-old man presented with a persistent cough, multiple bilateral pulmonary nodules, intrathoracic lymphadenopathy, a partially calcified left supraclavicular lymph node, a left thyroid nodule, and left level IV neck lymph nodes with calcifications. What is your diagnosis?

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Biological Sex and Chronic Rhinosinusitis Diagnosis and Biomarkers

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Oral Nicotine Pouches—Concerns for Otolaryngologists
abstract: This Viewpoint discusses characteristics of oral nicotine pouches to highlight their potential to present concerns for otolaryngologists.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Midline Tongue Defect in a Pediatric Patient
abstract: A male infant presented with an anterior midline tongue indentation. What is your diagnosis?

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Reflux Medication and Supraglottoplasty in Infant Laryngomalacia
abstract: To the Editor The study by Zalzal et al examining the association between gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) medications and supraglottoplasty rates in infants with laryngomalacia is commendable, especially their efforts to assemble an impressive cohort of 395 infants. Nonetheless, we note a few important methodological issues that require further exploration.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Ossification of the Chorda Tympani Nerve
abstract: This case report describes a patient who presented with isolated left-sided conductive hearing loss.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: Reflux Medication and Supraglottoplasty in Infant Laryngomalacia—Reply
abstract: In Reply We thank Nafiu for her letter, which raised 3 thoughtful points for response. First, our study adhered to the standard of care, in which patients are treated by appropriate specialists based on their presenting symptoms. We respectfully but firmly reject the assertion that we omitted crucial comparisons of key clinical factors that guided treatment. As explained in the Methods of our article, infants were included based on a presentation of stridor, aspiration, apnea, or failure to thrive. As qualified airway specialists, the decision to treat patients is based on the flexible endoscopic evaluations for respiratory symptoms and airway inflammation, so these factors were not omitted. Additionally, clinical signs of stridor or aspiration were explicitly evaluated in conjunction with weight, prematurity, and other factors. The concern that this patient population was not randomized leads to confusion on our part, as true randomization is not possible in a retrospective cohort study because randomization requires actively assigning participants to groups. The standard of care for managing laryngomalacia dictates that patients are treated by appropriate physicians for their symptoms, whether airway (otolaryngology) or acid reflux (pediatrics/gastroenterology), and these standards were not altered for the sake of randomization.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Current Issue
title: AI Model for Imaging-Based Extranodal Extension Detection in Human HPV-Positive Oropharyngeal Cancer
abstract: This cohort study develops an artificial intelligence–driven pipeline for classification of lymph node segmentation and imaging-based extranodal extension using pretreatment computed tomography for prognoses in human papilloma virus–positive oropharyngeal cancer.

journal: JAMA Otolaryngology–Head & Neck Surgery Online First
title: Cochlear Implant User Affect and Reported Quality of Life
abstract: This study assesses whether affect and quality-of-life scores change, and extent to which affect is associated, in patients who received cochlear implants at a single tertiary otolaryngology referral center.

title: A Novel Application-Based Test for Rapid Screening of Olfactory Dysfunction
abstract: This diagnostic study evaluates the performance of a novel, self-administered mobile application–based screening tool for the detection of olfactory dysfunction among US adults.

title: A Patient With Recurrent Pleomorphic Adenomas
abstract: A 31-year-old female presented with a progressively enlarging left submandibular mass and history of pleomorphic adenoma of the left submandibular gland. What is your diagnosis?

title: Clinical Trial Termination or Withdrawal in Head and Neck Squamous Cell Carcinoma
